questions.question_text:
You have been invited to a public cloud design and architecture session to help deliver secure east west flows and secure Kubernetes workloads.

What deployment options do you have available? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
B. VM-Series
D. CN-Series

VM-Series is a next-generation firewall solution that can be deployed in public cloud environments to protect east-west flows and workloads. CN-Series is specifically designed to integrate with Kubernetes environments, providing security for container workloads in the cloud.

Selected Answer: BD
I think D should be included as well as B. The official study guide on pg 102 says "CN-Series is the container native version of the ML-powered Next-Generation Firewall (NGFW)
that is designed specifically for Kubernetes environments. CN-Series container firewalls help
network security teams safeguard developers with deep security integration into Kubernetes
orchestration. Deploy the CN-Series to secure traffic between pods in different trust zones and namespaces, for protection against known and zero-day malware, and to block data exfiltration from your containerized environments.

Selected Answer: B
Zero-day threat: The window of vulnerability that exists from the time a new (unknown)
threat is released until security vendors release a signature file or security patch for the
threat

choices.D: A specific day during which zero threats occurred
choices.C: The day a software vendor becomes aware of an exploit and prevents any further hacking
choices.A: The amount of time it takes to discover a vulnerability and release a security fix
choices.B: The period between the discovery of a vulnerability and development and release of a patch

questions.question_text: What is the definition of a zero-day threat?
What differentiates knowledge-based systems from behavior-based systems?

choices.D: Behavior-based systems pull from a previously stored database that distinguishes “bad”.
choices.B: Knowledge-based systems pull from a previously stored database that distinguishes “bad”.
choices.A: Behavior-based systems find the data that knowledge-based systems store.
choices.C: Knowledge-based systems try to find new, distinct traits to find “bad” things.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
seems to be the correct answer

Selected Answer: B
Behavior-based systems are designed to find new and distinct traits or patterns that could indicate malicious or abnormal activity, whereas knowledge-based systems use pre-existing knowledge to make determinations.

Selected Answer: B
2.18.1 Differentiate between knowledge-based and behavior-based systems

Selected Answer: B
Knowledge based = Signature based according to what i read.
Study Guide p103
references:
https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cyberpedia/what-is-an-intrusion-prevention-system-ips
https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cyberpedia/what-is-an-intrusion-detection-system-ids

Selected Answer: A
Connectors and interfaces are required for a SIEM to ensure the flow of data to the SIEM data lake. The correct answer is A.
SIEM Connector are used to read various logs and forwarding them to your SIEM Platform in a standardized format. Interfaces are various tool in the SIEM Platform.

questions.question_text: What is required for a SIEM to operate correctly to ensure a translated flow from the system of interest to the SIEM data lake?
Which activities do local organization security policies cover for a SaaS application?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
he correct answer is:

B. How the application can be used
Explanation:
Local organization security policies for a SaaS (Software as a Service) application typically define guidelines and rules for how employees or users within the organization can use the application. These policies address:

Acceptable use of the application
Access control and user permissions
Data sharing and privacy rules
Compliance requirements for the organization's data handling
Security measures like password policies and multi-factor authentication (MFA)

Selected Answer: B
B. how the application can be used

The local organisation's security policies for a SaaS application typically cover how the application can be used. This includes guidelines on access, configuration and proper use of the application to ensure that security and compliance with organisational standards are maintained.

Option C. how the application processes the data is also relevant, as security policies may include how information is handled and processed within the application to ensure data protection and regulatory compliance.

However, in the context of organisational security policies for SaaS applications, it is more common to focus on how the application can be used (option B), as this covers practical aspects of access and use of the application by users, and policies usually define the rules for secure use of the application.

Both options are important in the context of security, but option B is more directly applicable to usage policies within an organisation.

choices.B: how the application can be used
choices.A: how the data is backed up in one or more locations
choices.D: how the application can transit the Internet
choices.C: how the application processes the data
